Sun of Faith - English: Then the Bodhisattva went to a cave surrounded by flowers and fruit trees. But as soon as he sat down, the mountain crumbled.
Inscription - English: Seated on a rock mountain, the mountain crumbled
Manual - English: The Buddha leaves the rocky hill after a sliding of rocks. Nāga King, Kālika (dus can) praises the Buddha. A grass-seller named Svastika (bkra shis) and his servants offer grass to the Buddha. The Buddha leaves for Bodhgaya (byang chub snying po).

Sun of Faith - English: "Your pure roots of virtue are so perfected that there is nowhere on earth that can support you!" said the gods. "But there is such a place close by, called Vajrasana. Now go there."
The gods showed the way as he walked along and lotus-flowers emerged in the places where his feet fell. Lotus pools formed as water from the four oceans poured into the depressions.

The Bodhisattva continued on his way and each great footfall resounded like metal drum struck with a stick. Birds and animals surrounded the Bodhisattva. The gods misted him with a light rain and fanned him with a gentle breeze.
In the Nairanjana River there lived a serpent-deity king named Kalika, who was blind most of the time but regained his sight when a buddha appeared in the world.
He saw Krakucchanda and other buddha's of the past. And at this time he was likewise able to see.
When he heard the great sound the earth made, he left his dwelling and rose to the surface of the earth. He saw the Blessed One from far off and knew he would certainly become a buddha.

He praised the Bodhisattva at length, saying such things as,

"The powerful buddhas,
That I have seen before:
Looking at you, Sage,
You are no different than them!"
As he went along, he encountered the grass seller Svastika, who had been placed there by Indra. He carried a load of grass gathered from Gandamadana, soft and pleasing to the touch.

The Bodhisattva begged for the grass and Svastika offered it with devotion.

**In response to the Bodhisattva’s request, Svastika joyously and with reverence, offered the sheaf of stalks to him.
Inscription - English: Receives kuśa grass from the grass seller Svastika

Sun of Faith - English: The he continued on to Bodhimanda and ascended the Vajrasana, the "Indestructable Throne." At the foot of an Ashvata tree, the tree of awakening, he cast down the grass bundle for a seating mat. The grass fell in a clockwise pattern, neither too thick nor too thin.

From here down, this could be an additional scene, with the figure of the Buddha seated on grass matt at Vajrasana.

Sun of Faith - English: By this, he knew without doubt he would attain the realization of unexcelled wisdom. So he sat in the cross-legged vajra position, with his posture erect, and his mind settled. And he made this vow: "Until I attain unexcelled enlightenment, I will not uncross my legs."
